page.title: 05Pendomer: Farming 1
page.content: Except for two areas of woodland, Pen Wood and Coker Wood, the villages of Pendomer and Halstock, and the reservoir, the whole block is given over to farming. Dairying is by far the most important enterprise. There are some ten or a dozen farms, typically of between 200 and 400 acres, with perhaps 100 dairy cows on average - Friesian cross - and on the larger farms a Hereford cross bull. These farms raise their own calves, replacing the dairy herd from their own stock and producing beef; the smaller units sell the calves and buy replacement heifers as necessary. Some have a few sheep in addition, either raising lambs or, more probably, over-wintering sheep from other areas. Some of the farm houses are old, but with extensive modern farm buildings; other farm houses are post-war.
